item.title: February 9, 2026
item.content:encoded:
Pi is such a cool project. It makes me think in whole other ways about working with LLMs. No more magice, all logic is put in place by me. I still like OpenCode as well. But using Pi I now better understand what‚Äôs happening.

AI may make you more productive, but working more and more‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not alone: https://x.com/simonw/status/2020901645597683870?s=46

This shows the power of Pi, if you can imagine it, you can build it: https://github.com/nicobailon/pi-prompt-template-model

Building a little bot for slack with AI using Claude Opus 4.6. Without asking, it builds integration with OpenAI‚Äôs API. Why didn‚Äôt it favor Claude SDK? Now that I switch to OpenRouter it becomes apparent that OpenRouter and Ollama are all using the OpenAI API, so I think OpenAI API is just more common.

Just set up a Slack bot in about 1h to add messages to my moments (https://github.com/jgordijn/moments-slackbot). This message was created via Slack. The power we get! An idea is now realized in no time üí™

In rule form: ‚Ä¢ Code must not be written by humans ‚Ä¢ Code must not be reviewed by humans Finally, in practical form: ‚Ä¢ If you haven‚Äôt spent at least $1,000 on tokens today per human engineer, your software factory has room for improvement

Nice. No more coding by hand. No more reviewing. Tokens as a measure of effectiveness üòé

Tests can be reward hacked - we needed validation that was less vulnerable to the model cheating

Building a digital Twin of services to allow for massive integration testing. Create tests, not accessible by the agents. Instead of a Boolean test, write a probabilistic and empirical one. ü§Ø

item.title: February 8, 2026
item.content:encoded:
Going to experiment with adding a microblog to the site. The idea is simple: quick notes and observations that don‚Äôt need the full treatment of a blog post. Sometimes you just want to jot down a thought. Inspired by the ‚ÄúMoments‚Äù section on aishepherd.nl by Jeroen Dee.

How to secure your agent? You can‚Äôt. You can try to put some instructions, but if it has bash access, it can just do about everything.

A huge part of working with agents is discovering their limits. The limits keep moving right now, which means constant re-learning. But if you try some penny-saving cheap model like Sonnet, or a second rate local model, you do worse than waste your time, you learn the wrong lessons.
